Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They notice the need to use protective equipment and follow hygiene steps more consistently.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story: I stood in the staff locker room, my hands trembling as I pulled on the disposable gloves. As a housekeeping cleaner, I was expected to follow every safety and hygiene protocol, especially today, when a stomach flu outbreak had swept through the building. The supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “No shortcuts. Protective equipment at all times.” I glanced at the clock—just an hour until the most significant religious holiday of the year. As the community’s priest, I was expected to lead the prayers, to be present for every soul who would gather, seeking comfort and guidance. My phone buzzed with messages from parishioners: “We need you tonight, Father.” I could picture the crowded sanctuary, the candles, the hopeful faces. But here, in the harsh fluorescent light, I saw the mop, the disinfectant, the duty to protect others from illness. My heart pounded with the weight of both roles, each demanding my full presence, each vital in its own way. I stared at my reflection, torn between the sacred and the sanitary, knowing I could not be in two places at once.
